newsitem.title: GERMANY: Waigel insists on tough reading of EMU goals.
newsitem.headline: Waigel insists on tough reading of EMU goals.

text.p: Members of German Finance Minister Theo Waigel's Christian Social Union on Friday insisted the party agreed on a tough interpretation of the fiscal entry criteria to Europe's planned currency union.

Asked about speculation that his party had fallen into bitter infighting as Germany scrambled to ready itself for currency union, Waigel said: "The CSU has closed ranks and will appear united at today's party meeting."
Joachim Herrmann, the party's newly appointed deputy general secretary, said: "As far as I know there are no disagreements between (Bavarian state premier Edmund) Stoiber and Waigel."

Asked about speculation earlier this week that Waigel had distanced himself from his hardline interpretation of budget deficit criterion, Herrmann said: "In our policy draft we say that new indebtedness may not as a rule exceed 3%, and that means 3.0 and that is it."
